body:
Problem: We are missing the option for Vim's `previewpopup`.

Solution: Implement the `previewpopup` option. However, our floating window is different from Vim's, so some available keys in the `previewpopup`  differ from Vim.

Fix #9920

```lua

```

This has implications like removing duplicates when using `:set+=`.

comment_data.body: Looks like this skips the epilogue at the end of the function that resets `&scrollbind` and such (which `win_float_create` also doesn't seem to do)

I'd continue calling it a floating window and maybe reword a few things too, something like:

```suggestion
Alternatively, a floating window can be used by setting the 'previewpopup'
option.  When set, it overrules the 'previewwindow' and 'previewheight'
settings.  The option is a comma-separated list of values:
`border`, `height`, `width`, `title`, `title_pos`, `footer`, `footer_pos`.
See |nvim_open_win()| for details.
Note that `border` only supports string values.
```

comment_data.body: Nit, but above this, the line `bool use_float = strstr(p_cot, "popup") != NULL ? true : false;` doesn't need the ternary.

This isn't true for Nvim (it's from [v8.1.1813](https://github.com/vim/vim/commit/2debf1c16b93f8693a785f675320d9e949c96a97)), but maybe this swapexists behaviour should be ported given that the popup is `focusable = false`.

This all said, maybe Nvim preview popups (well, floats) should allow focusing anyway, as we're not bound to the same limitations as Vim's popups in regards to editing.

+Example: >vim
+        :set previewpopup=border:double,height:10,width:60
+
+A few peculiarities:
+- If the file is in a buffer already, it will be re-used.  This will allow for
+  editing the file while it's visible in the popup window.
+- No ATTENTION dialog will be used, since you can't edit the file in the popup
+  window.  However, if you later open the same buffer in a normal window, you
+  may not notice it's edited elsewhere.  And when then using ":edit" to
+  trigger the ATTENTION and responding "A" for Abort, the preview window will
+  become empty.

comment_data.body:
"float" is ambiguous. we should always say "floatwin" or win_float.
```suggestion
bool win_float_parse_option(WinConfig *config)
```

was this copied from vim? or generated by AI? :) we have lots of similar code like `parse_winborder`, `parse_win_config`, `parse_border_style`. why do we need even more ? 

and if it's really needed, the name should make it more clear that this is specifically for 'previewpopup'. The name `parse_float_option` is very unclear. A clearer name would be `parse_previewpopu_option`.

Also, should this live in `optionstr.c` ?

code in popupwin.c handles this option in Vim. Here's how I've modified it to make it clearer.

https://github.com/vim/vim/blob/68ee1cf7de36bdd6e642807c8beda751112aaab8/src/popupwin.c#L1778-L1904

I have removed these `parse_opt_*` functions .. If you still feel it's too long, then maybe as you said, we could handle some comma-list options in Lua and replace certain C functions.

comment_regular_data.body:
> From a usability standpoint, Vim's preview popups feel much better to use, as their sizes scale to fit the content, even when it changes (the width and height for its previewpopup is a minimum value, not an exact).

Oh i think i know how to do it . and something not correct now.
two things. https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/25541 is completepopup see `:h complete-popup` in vim and #25541 also support add border to pum which vim doesn't have.

Most of the C code here is just to parse an option. That's kind of crazy. Maybe it's time we started doing that in Lua, in a new file like `runtime/lua/vim/_core/options.lua`, then use `NLUA_EXEC_STATIC` to run it. It's just insane that we keep shoveling tons of C code just to parse strings.

Or maybe there's existing C functions that can be re-used, instead of all the new code here.

> Maybe it's time we started doing that in Lua, in a new file like runtime/lua/vim/_core/options.lua

give it a try.
